heroDescription: The MSPSRπ project was the second phase of our pulsar astrometry program, focusing exclusively on millisecond pulsars (MSPs) from 2014 to 2018. This phase targeted 18 MSPs with the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA), achieving sub-milliarcsecond precision for parallax and proper motion measurements.
overview: The MSPSRπ project was designed as a dedicated follow-up to the original PSRπ project, with a targeted focus on millisecond pulsars (MSPs) that are critical for tests of gravity and gravitational wave detection through pulsar timing arrays (PTAs).

Using the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA), we conducted a series of observations of 18 carefully selected MSPs over a 4-year period. By implementing advanced phase-referencing techniques, we achieved unprecedented astrometric precision for these distant cosmic timekeepers.

The project resulted in 15 significant parallax measurements, roughly tripling the small number of MSPs with well-measured astrometric parameters. These measurements have contributed to enhanced tests of gravitational theories, improved our understanding of the Galactic electron distribution, and provided insights into the kinematic properties of the MSP population.

objectives.title: Precise Distance Measurements
objectives.description: Determine parallax-based distances to millisecond pulsars with uncertainty < 10% to provide model-independent distance measurements.

objectives.title: Proper Motion Determination
objectives.description: Measure precise proper motions to determine transverse velocities and correct for Shklovskii effects in pulsar timing parameters.

objectives.title: Enhance Gravitational Tests
objectives.description: Provide independent astrometric parameters to improve tests of general relativity and alternative theories of gravity with binary pulsar systems.

objectives.title: Pulsar Timing Array Enhancement
objectives.description: Improve the sensitivity of pulsar timing arrays for gravitational wave detection by providing model-independent astrometric parameters.

objectives.title: Pulsar Population Studies
objectives.description: Investigate the kinematic properties and spatial distribution of millisecond pulsars to constrain their formation and evolutionary history.

technicalApproach: MSPSRπ utilized the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) at L-band (1.4 GHz) to achieve the highest possible astrometric precision. The observations were designed to maximize parallax sensitivity by scheduling sessions near the times of maximum parallactic excursion.

We implemented relayed phase-referencing techniques, where a secondary phase reference source very close to the target pulsar was observed to refine direction-dependent calibration effects. For three pulsars, we employed 1D interpolation to further suppress propagation-related systematic errors.

Pulsar gating was applied during correlation to improve the signal-to-noise ratio, effectively leveraging our knowledge of the pulsars' rotational phases to exclude off-pulse data. This resulted in an average improvement in sensitivity of a factor of approximately 1.8.

All data was processed with our custom psrvlbireduce pipeline, which automates many aspects of the calibration and imaging process. Systematic error analysis was performed using a Bayesian approach with the sterne package, specifically developed for this project.

keyResults.title: Double Neutron Star System Distance
keyResults.description: Achieved the most significant model-independent distance measurement ever made for a double neutron star system (PSR J1518+4904), with a precision of 0.81 ± 0.02 kpc.

keyResults.title: Refined Orbital Decay Tests
keyResults.description: Enhanced tests of orbital decay in binary systems PSR J1012+5307 and PSR J1738+0333, placing new constraints on dipole gravitational radiation and the time derivative of Newton's gravitational constant.

keyResults.title: Interstellar Medium Characterization
keyResults.description: Detected significant angular broadening for PSR J1643-1224, allowing independent verification of the association between the HII region Sh 2-27 and the main scattering screen of this pulsar.

keyResults.title: Gamma-ray Pulsar Death Line
keyResults.description: Refined the upper limit of the death line of γ-ray-emitting pulsars using the intrinsic spin-down power of PSR J1730-2304, the least energetic γ-ray pulsar known.

scientificImpact: The MSPSRπ program has made significant contributions to multiple areas of pulsar astrophysics. By providing model-independent distances and proper motions for millisecond pulsars, we have enhanced the precision of gravitational tests with binary pulsar systems.

Our results have helped discriminate between competing models of the Galactic electron density distribution, which is crucial for understanding the interstellar medium and interpreting dispersion measures of pulsars and fast radio bursts.

The precise space velocities derived from our measurements have provided insights into the formation mechanisms of millisecond pulsars, suggesting a more complex evolutionary history than previously thought.

dataPipeline.description: All MSPSRπ data was processed using a standardized pipeline specifically developed for pulsar astrometry. This approach ensures consistent results across all sources and enables systematic error analysis.

steps.title: VLBA Correlation with Pulsar Gating
steps.description: Raw data correlated using the DiFX software correlator with pulsar gating applied to improve signal-to-noise ratio.

steps.title: Primary Calibration
steps.description: Initial calibration performed on the primary phase calibrator, including bandpass, amplitude, and phase calibration.

steps.title: Secondary Calibrator Self-Calibration
steps.description: Self-calibration applied to the in-beam (secondary) calibrator to refine direction-dependent calibration effects.

steps.title: Target Imaging
steps.description: Application of calibration solutions to target pulsar data and creation of interferometric images.

steps.title: Position Measurement
steps.description: Precise position measurement through fitting to the interferometric image, with error estimation.

steps.title: Astrometric Parameter Inference
steps.description: Bayesian inference of astrometric parameters (position, proper motion, parallax) using the sterne package, accounting for systematic errors.
